intro: The muscles are collective capabilities developed through practicing Hautū Waka. They're organised using Te Whare Tapa Whā — the Māori wellbeing model — as a structure. Like a house with four walls and a foundation, all must be strong for the structure to stand.

dimensions.name: Whenua
dimensions.description: Whenua is the foundation upon which the whare stands. Without this grounding, the four walls cannot hold.

muscles.name: Rootedness and Belonging
muscles.description: Connection to place shapes identity. Knowing where you come from helps you navigate where you're going.

muscles.name: Relationship with Environment
muscles.description: Environment isn't backdrop — it's relation. Reciprocal relationship with places and spaces you inhabit.

muscles.name: Environmental Awareness and Immersion
muscles.description: Being involved in the world rather than abstracting from it. Environment communicates constantly.

muscles.name: Continuous Adaptation with Place
muscles.description: Place changes. You change. Staying connected means refreshing understanding continuously.

muscles.name: Temporal Submission
muscles.description: Place has its own rhythms. Growing happens according to the logic of context, not urgency of the grower.

muscles.name: Compost and Return
muscles.description: What dies enables growth to continue. Old patterns, identities, certainties — their dissolution creates conditions for what comes next.

dimensions.name: Taha Tinana
dimensions.description: The physical dimension — body awareness, sensory perception, and embodied practice.

muscles.name: Body Awareness and Somatic Intelligence
muscles.description: Your body registers information before your conscious mind does. Tension, ease, gut responses are data.

muscles.name: Sensory Perception
muscles.description: Intelligence comes through all senses, not just sight.

muscles.name: Limits and Rest
muscles.description: Bodies have limits. Exhaustion isn't an obstacle to overcome but information about what's sustainable.

muscles.name: Restraint as Embodied Practice
muscles.description: Not-doing takes practice. The body learns to hold back, pause before acting.

dimensions.name: Taha Wairua
dimensions.description: The spiritual dimension — connection to purpose, ancestry, mystery, and endings.

muscles.name: Connection to Ancestral Knowledge
muscles.description: Tūpuna had been doing this for ages. Traditional practices contain wisdom tested over generations.

muscles.name: Purpose and Orientation
muscles.description: Work connects to something larger than immediate tasks. Purpose provides orientation when conditions shift.

muscles.name: Comfort with Mystery and Uncertainty
muscles.description: Not everything can be known in advance. Emergence is real. Certainty is often illusion.

muscles.name: Working with Endings
muscles.description: Everything ends. Spiritual maturity includes orienting toward mortality without rancour.

muscles.name: Acceptance of the Uncontrollable
muscles.description: Some things can't be changed by effort. Finding equanimity with what must be accepted.

dimensions.name: Taha Whānau
dimensions.description: The social dimension — relationships, collective process, recognition, and shared grief.

muscles.name: Relational Intelligence
muscles.description: Relationships aren't just context for work — they are the work. Quality of relationships determines what becomes possible.

muscles.name: Collective Sense-Making
muscles.description: Understanding emerges through collective process, not individual genius.

muscles.name: Recognition and Reciprocity
muscles.description: Seeing and acknowledging others' mana and potential. Relationships characterised by mutual respect.

muscles.name: Productive Friction
muscles.description: Honest collective work involves disagreement, tension, struggle. Conflict isn't failure of relationship.

muscles.name: Grief and Release in Collective Contexts
muscles.description: Collectives lose members. Collective grief — acknowledging loss together — is how groups remain capable of forming new attachments.

dimensions.name: Taha Hinengaro
dimensions.description: The mental and emotional dimension — presence, pattern recognition, multiple intelligences, and the discipline of waiting.

muscles.name: Mindfulness and Presence
muscles.description: Being fully present to what's happening now, rather than ruminating on past or worrying about future.

muscles.name: Emotional Awareness and Processing
muscles.description: Emotions are information. Fear, excitement, resistance — all signal something worth attending to. Includes emotional granularity.

muscles.name: Pattern Recognition and Triangulation
muscles.description: Seeing connections between seemingly separate things. Never trusting single data points.

muscles.name: Multiple Ways of Knowing
muscles.description: Rational analysis is one tool among many. Intuition, embodied knowing, emotional intelligence — all valid.

muscles.name: Cyclic and Non-Linear Thinking
muscles.description: Process isn't always forward progression. Cycling back is part of navigation.

muscles.name: Tolerance for Frustration
muscles.description: Innovation is struggle. Frustration isn't sign of failure — it's the texture of the work.

muscles.name: Discipline of Not-Acting
muscles.description: Sitting with incompletion takes mental discipline. Resisting premature closure.
